Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Concise (Uses short sentences, answers strictly 'yes' or 'no', and avoids elaboration.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Growth concerns; since birth
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Facial dysmorphism; hearing defect; bony abnormality; delayed motor milestones; difficulty remaining seated or concentrating; IQ 56 at 12 months
Medical_Record.Background: Normal pregnancy; birth weight 2.9 kg (10th percentile); birth length 45 cm (3rd percentile); no foramen magnum or spine column deformity; no family history of same mutation; mother, brother unaffected

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Bulging forehead; prominent ears; widely spaced eyes; down slanted palpebral fissures; short nose with broad columella; thick alae nasi and septum; thick, everted underlip; short, fleshy hands; hyperextensible, tapering fingers; small terminal phalanges and nails; weight at 12 months 8.2 kg; height 68.2 cm (<-3.17 z score); unable to stand unaided at 12 months
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Bone metabolism disturbance (Vit D 45.2 nmol/L); IGF-1α < 25 ng/mL; ABR threshold >85 db (hearing disorder); MRI: dilation of bilateral ventricles, less cerebral white matter; NGS: c.2185 C > T at chrX20173554 (p.Arg729Trp mutation, RSK2 instability); mutation not found in mother or brother

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Frustrated (Complains about symptoms, challenges the doctor's questions, and sounds irritable.), Speaking Style: Confused (Misunderstands questions, asks for repetition, and gives unrelated answers.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Desire to postpone second pregnancy; request for reversible contraception
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Wishes to delay second pregnancy for approximately 3 years; seeks contraceptive method that can be discontinued when ready for conception
Medical_Record.Background: One child; no additional medical, surgical, family, social history, medications, allergies, or contextual data provided

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Hesitant (Uses fillers like 'um' or 'maybe', pauses often, and avoids direct commitment.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Right flank pain; 2-month duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Persistent right flank pain; no hematuria; no dysuria; no thyroid disease; no renal disease
Medical_Record.Background: No significant past medical history; blood group O negative; BMI 19.8 kg/m2; slightly increased blood pressure; no weight loss; no family or social history mentioned; no medication or allergy history provided

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Abdomen smooth; no tenderness; no flank masses; rest of examination unremarkable
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Blood tests normal; HGB 11.1 g/dl; Creatinine 0.61 mg/dl; abdominal ultrasound: heterogeneous mass 13 × 14 cm right kidney; MSCT: large right centrally necrotized tumor, homogenously enhancing; no distant metastases; no lymph node enlargement; no ovarian mass; stones in left kidney; post-nephrectomy: tumor mass 13.5 × 12.5 cm lower lobe; histopathology: macro and micro follicles with eosinophilic colloid-like material, cuboidal cells, no mitoses, no capsule invasion; immunohistochemistry: Vimentin positive, CK19 diffusely positive, CK7 focally positive, TTf1, Thyroglobulin, WT1, CD10, EMA negative

Diagnosis: Thyroid-like follicular carcinoma of the kidney

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Upper abdominal discomfort; unspecified duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Diagnosed with cholangiocarcinoma; attempted laparoscopic resection not performed due to peritoneal seeding; treated with gemcitabine and cisplatin chemotherapy; transferred for further management
Medical_Record.Background: No details on occupation, PMH, surgical history, family or social history, medications, allergies, immunizations, or travel

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Vital signs within normal ranges at admission
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Peripheral blood: leukocyte 4920/μL, hemoglobin 10.0 g/dL, platelet 359,000/μL; serum biochemistry within normal ranges; abdominal CT: tumor size increased after 2 cycles of chemotherapy; immunohistochemical staining for TP positive; abdominal CT after gemcitabine and doxifluridine: partial response, then progression; CT during follow-up: disease progression; death due to sepsis

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Genital pruritus; 1-year duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Intense pruritus during menstruation; no oral contraceptive intake; no seasonal change; no contact hypersensitivity
Medical_Record.Background: Peptic ulcer for 2 years; no family history of similar complaints or genital lesions

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Symmetrical lichenified plaques on bilateral labia majora; abrasion and erythema on vulvar edges; otherwise normal skin; no extragenital lesions
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Papanicolaou smear and vulvar swabs negative for pathology and infection; histopathology shows multiple cystic enlargements lined by cuboidal epithelium, tadpole-like ductal structures, eosinophilic material in fibrotic stroma; ER and PR immunostains negative; fasting glucose 280 mg/dL; HbA1c 12.24 mmol/mL

Diagnosis: Vulvar syringoma and type 2 diabetes mellitus

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Routine follow-up for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Episode of macroscopic haematuria two months prior; controlled by conservative treatment; remained asymptomatic
Medical_Record.Background: History of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease diagnosed 8 years prior; mild arterial hypertension for 8 years; treated with telmisartan 80 mg daily

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Slight arterial hypertension; otherwise normal physical and neurological examination
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Serum creatinine 2 mg/dl; creatinine clearance 34 ml/min/1.73 m2; abdominal ultrasonography shows enlarged cystic kidneys with few liver cysts; MRI reveals numerous renal cysts, some with recent bleeding; total kidney volume 3053 ml; incidental sacral radicular cysts with fluid content and homogenous high T2 signal intensity

Diagnosis: Sacral radicular cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Calm (Responds objectively, focuses on facts, and keeps a steady tone.), Speaking Style: Concise (Uses short sentences, answers strictly 'yes' or 'no', and avoids elaboration.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Acute decompensated heart failure; duration not specified
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: History of carotid artery dissection and metastatic melanoma; received combination checkpoint inhibitor therapy (ipilimumab, nivolumab) one year prior; switched to dabrafenib and trametinib due to disease progression; nivolumab restarted four months prior; developed asymptomatic supraventricular tachycardia one month prior; subsequent dyspnoea before hospitalization
Medical_Record.Background: Metastatic melanoma; carotid artery dissection; prior immunotherapy (ipilimumab, nivolumab); BRAF inhibitors (dabrafenib, trametinib); no data on family history, social history, allergies, immunizations, or travel

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Afebrile; hypotensive; tachycardic; tachypnoeic; pulmonary oedema; jugular venous distension; ascites; lower extremity oedema
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: ECG: regular, narrow-complex rhythm, atrial tachycardia, no ischaemic changes; serum troponins negative; CK negative; proBNP 3797 pg/mL (elevated); echocardiogram: global biventricular failure, LVEF 26%, severely dilated left ventricle, trivial pericardial effusion; CMR: non-ischaemic late gadolinium enhancement, mid-wall and epicardial enhancement, 15% LV myocardium involved, severe biventricular dysfunction (LVEF 16%, RV ejection fraction 12%); microscopy: moderate lymphocytic myocarditis in LGE regions, mild infiltrate elsewhere, T-cell predominant (CD4+, CD8+), moderate fibrosis, PD-L1 focal membrane positivity; autopsy: no significant coronary artery disease

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Denial (Downplays pain, insists symptoms are minor, and dismisses severity.), Speaking Style: Verbose (Over-explains, includes irrelevant backstory, and rambles off-topic.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Severe itchy erythematous patches; duration since childhood, worsening over past 8–10 years
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Itchy erythematous patches started on limbs, progressed to trunk; worsening over 8–10 years; initial cyclosporine 20 mg BID for 2 months with worsening symptoms; cyclosporine increased to 100 mg BID plus methotrexate up to 20 mg weekly with 60% improvement; subsequent flare-up; started on dupilumab 300 mg every 2 weeks for 4 months; redness on face and neck 4 hours post-injection, resolving after 2 days, recurring after each injection; rash became scaly before resolving; pain and warmth over redness rated 7/10; no fever, itching, or swelling of lips/eyelids; hydroxyzine and mometasone furoate cream BID for 3 days used during episodes, rash faded after 2 days
Medical_Record.Background: History of atopic dermatitis since childhood; no mention of surgical history, family history, social history, allergies, immunizations, or travel

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Non-pruritic skin rash over cheeks and neck; no palpable lymph nodes; no hepatosplenomegaly
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Laboratory workup unremarkable; negative antinuclear antibody; erythrocyte sedimentation rate 21 mm/h (normal)

Diagnosis: Dupilumab-induced facial and neck erythema in atopic dermatitis

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Severe hip pain and rigid immobility; 3-day duration after hip resurfacing arthroplasty
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Persistent severe pain and rigid immobility of left hip following resurfacing arthroplasty; flection contracture on right side; groin pain
Medical_Record.Background: Recent resurfacing arthroplasty for osteoarthritis of left hip; posterior approach with computer navigation; Birmingham Hip Resurfacing implant; no further medical, family, social history, medications, or allergies mentioned

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Flection contracture on right side; groin pain
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: X-ray shows mismatch between femoral and acetabular component diameters; coordinate measuring machine confirms size mismatch and damage to femoral component

Diagnosis: Hip resurfacing arthroplasty failure due to mismatched implant components

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Itching, foreign body sensation, severe photophobia in right eye; 1-week duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Progressive discomfort, photophobia, decreasing vision, tearing in right eye over several months; intermittent pain; history of loss to follow-up; worsening symptoms after initial improvement
Medical_Record.Background: No background medical history, surgical history, family or social history, medications, allergies, or other contextual data provided

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Visual acuity: finger counting (right), 20/40 (left); intraocular pressure: 11 mm Hg (right), 18 mm Hg (left); 360-degree peripheral corneal thinning with central corneal protrusion bilaterally; right eye: 1+ conjunctival injection, 3+ corneal edema, Descemet membrane tear from 4–7 o'clock, 15-mm horizontal cornea; mild corneal neovascularization and hydrops (right); conjunctival injection with corneal bullae (right); corneal scar with bullae (right); postoperative: DSEK graft stable, hydrops with well-formed anterior chamber, cornea clear, DSEK graft stable at 8 months
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Pentacam (left): 478 μm central cornea, 323 μm peripheral cornea, 50.9 D K-max; imaging of right eye not obtained due to irregular and hazy cornea; B scan normal

Diagnosis: Bilateral keratoglobus with chronic hydrops secondary to spontaneous Descemet membrane tear (right eye)

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Chest pain, heartburn, dysphagia after radiation therapy
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Oral carcinoma with multiple bone metastases; received 3 cycles of 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, and cetuximab; radiation therapy to thoracic and lumbar vertebrae; developed chest pain, heartburn, dysphagia post-radiation
Medical_Record.Background: No additional PMH, surgical history, family or social history, medications, allergies, or other contextual data provided

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: PET/CT: bone metastases to thoracic and lumbar vertebrae; blood neutrophil count <500/μL post-chemotherapy; upper GI endoscopy: esophageal erythema, ulceration, spontaneous bleeding (FARE grade 4, CTCAE grade 3); follow-up endoscopy: improvement to FARE grade 1, CTCAE grade 0; blood neutrophil count recovered to 4,900/μL

Medical_Record.Background: History of obesity, acute pancreatitis secondary to cholelithiasis, prior cholecystectomy, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, pulmonary embolism, nonischemic cardiomyopathy; medications: aspirin, apixaban, atorvastatin, metformin, metoprolol, spironolactone, ramipril; no alcohol use; recent use of Garcinia cambogia as appetite suppressant

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Epigastric tenderness; positive bowel sounds
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Serum lipase >600 U/L (elevated); WBC 11.7 K/μL (elevated); hemoglobin 13.4 g/dL; bilirubin 0.5 mg/dL; alkaline phosphatase 66 IU/L; ALT 12 U/L; AST 17 U/L; lactic acid 0.9 mmol/L; triglycerides 146 mg/dL; CT abdomen shows fat stranding around pancreas

Diagnosis: Acute pancreatitis secondary to Garcinia cambogia

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Verbose (Over-explains, includes irrelevant backstory, and rambles off-topic.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Sudden-onset skin thickening and hardening; rapid progression; 8-week duration after colorectal surgery
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Marked thickening and hardening of upper limb skin; sclerodactyly with flexural contractures of interphalangeal joints; hand stiffness; puffy fingers; digital pitting scars; lower extremity skin hardening with knee flexion contractures; facial skin hardening; limited mouth opening; microcheilia; mat-like telangiectasias on forehead and cheeks; Raynaud’s phenomenon; dyspeptic symptoms including heartburn, regurgitation, solid-food dysphagia; two years later, rapid progression of skin symptoms, fever, generalised malaise, abdominal pain
Medical_Record.Background: History of rectal adenocarcinoma; low anterior resection with protective transverse colostomy; pre-operative radiochemotherapy; adjuvant chemotherapy; no mention of family history, social history, medications, allergies, immunizations, or travel

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Marked skin thickening and hardening of upper limbs; sclerodactyly; flexural contractures of interphalangeal joints; hand stiffness; puffy fingers; digital pitting scars; lower extremity skin hardening; knee flexion contractures; facial skin hardening; limited mouth opening; microcheilia; mat-like telangiectasias on forehead and cheeks; nearly immobilising skin hardening of hands and lower extremities
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Raynaud’s phenomenon induced by cold-water provocation; early scleroderma pattern on nailfold capillaroscopy; high titres of antinuclear antibodies (1:1280) with nucleolar staining; negative western-blot for specific antigens; chest high-resolution CT shows bibasilar pulmonary fibrosis; preserved pulmonary function on spirometry; echocardiography not suggestive of pulmonary arterial hypertension; oesophageal manometry shows reduced distal contraction amplitude and hypotensive lower oesophageal sphincter; oncology assessment confirms inoperable, locally advanced recurrence of primary tumour

Diagnosis: Paraneoplastic systemic sclerosis associated with colorectal carcinoma

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Forgetful (Mixes up dates, frequently says 'I don't recall', and gives vague details.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Exertional dyspnea and palpitations during pregnancy; onset at 9 weeks gestation
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Known hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; chest tightness one year prior; rare palpitations before pregnancy; increased exertional dyspnea and palpitations upon fast walking or overeating at 9 weeks gestation; dizziness on orthostatic position change at 15 weeks gestation; symptoms persisted and worsened during pregnancy; progressive dyspnea on exertion and chest pain thirteen months after delivery
Medical_Record.Background: No previous medical history; no family history of cardiovascular disorder or sudden cardiac death; no surgical history; medications include bisoprolol 1.25 mg twice daily during pregnancy; no allergies mentioned; obstetric history: primigravid; fetal ultrasound normal

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Blood pressure 93/64 mm Hg; pulse rate 108 beats per minute; regular rhythm; grade III/VI systolic harsh murmur at third intercostal space left sternal border; breathing stable
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Electrocardiography: sinus rhythm; TTE: asymmetrical septal hypertrophy (15 mm), dynamic LVOT obstruction, severely enlarged left atrium (volume index 57 mL/m2), hyperdynamic LV systolic function (ejection fraction 78%), high LVOT pressure gradient (rest 75/47 mm Hg, Valsalva 103/52 mm Hg at 11 weeks; rest 119/52 mm Hg, Valsalva 147/70 mm Hg at 17 weeks; rest 125/63 mm Hg, Valsalva 152/72 mm Hg at 34 weeks; rest 115/66 mm Hg, Valsalva 152/83 mm Hg before delivery; rest 87/33 mm Hg after delivery; rest 100/31 mm Hg, Valsalva 169/45 mm Hg at 13 months postpartum), moderate eccentric mitral regurgitation (grade III/IV), pseudonormalization of LV filling pattern (E/e' 24); Holter monitoring: rare APCs and VPCs initially, later frequent APCs (4.26%), non-sustained atrial tachycardia, occasional VPCs (0.40%) up to triplets; fetal ultrasound normal

Diagnosis: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular outflow tract obstruction during pregnancy

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Frustrated (Complains about symptoms, challenges the doctor's questions, and sounds irritable.), Speaking Style: Hesitant (Uses fillers like 'um' or 'maybe', pauses often, and avoids direct commitment.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Swollen gums; duration not stated
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Discomfort due to gum disfigurement; unesthetic appearance; bleeding; difficulty chewing; symptoms more severe recently
Medical_Record.Background: Hypertension treated with amlodipine (10 mg/day for 2.5 years, increased to 50 mg/day 6 months ago); statins prescribed for acute angina attack and hypercholesterolemia; no other history provided

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Generalized gingival overgrowth on labial and lingual/palatal surfaces; more pronounced on labial surfaces; enlarged, fibrous, lobulated interdental papillae; generalized bleeding on probing; probing depths 3-8 mm; grade III mobility in mandibular anteriors; generalized reddish color; purulent discharge in mandibular anteriors; no deep periodontal pockets
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Plaque index, gingival index, Russel's periodontal index; photographic analysis (Ellis and Seymour score 3); radiograph shows generalized horizontal bone loss, more in anterior regions; blood tests for lipid profile (CHO, HDL, LDL, TG); genetic microbiologic test (IAI Pado Test 4.5) identified Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Porphyromonas gingivalis, Tannerella forsythia, Treponema denticola; biopsy shows dense and loose fibrous tissue, chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate, elongation of rete pegs

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Verbose (Over-explains, includes irrelevant backstory, and rambles off-topic.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Headache; 60-minute duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Sudden onset headache; mild dysarthria; left hemiparesis; left hemispatial neglect; no pain elsewhere; no trauma to head or neck
Medical_Record.Background: No signs of connective tissue diseases; no other past medical history, surgical history, family or social history, medications, allergies, immunizations, or travel history mentioned

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: NIH Stroke Scale score 9; mild dysarthria; left hemiparesis; left hemispatial neglect
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: MRI: right internal carotid artery occlusion without acute ischemic changes; angiography: right ICA occlusion, mural hematoma, dissection flap; cone-beam CT: no intracranial hemorrhage; post-procedure MRI: successful revascularization without infarction; follow-up angiography: resolution of dissection with minimal stenosis

Diagnosis: Acute internal carotid artery occlusion due to dissection of the paraclinoid segment

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Well-circumscribed, nontender, firm soft tissue mass on anterior abdominal wall; noted since birth
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Mass noted at birth; undetected on prenatal ultrasound; similar subcutaneous nodules on upper back and left hip; otherwise good health
Medical_Record.Background: Full-term birth; unremarkable prenatal course; no additional medical history provided

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Well-circumscribed, nontender, firm mass on anterior abdominal wall; subcutaneous nodules on upper back and left hip
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Abdominal ultrasound: left upper quadrant subcutaneous mass 1.9 x 1.2 x 2.7 cm; small vascular flow; MRI at ~2 months: multiple rim-enhancing lesions in abdomen and pelvis (osseous, muscular, pancreatic head); echocardiogram: 10-mm lesion in left ventricular free wall; biopsy: cystic mass fused to abdominal wall, tan-pink to tan-white, firm, rubbery; microscopy: bland, medium-sized, round to spindled cells, vacuolated nuclei, fascicular pattern, rare mitotic figures, collagenous fibromyxoid stroma; immunohistochemistry: positive for β-catenin (cytoplasmic), smooth muscle actin

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Verbose (Over-explains, includes irrelevant backstory, and rambles off-topic.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Suspected tongue cancer; duration not specified
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: History of Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosed 1 year and 5 months prior; received six courses of doxorubicin hydrochloride, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine; complete remission achieved; new tongue tumor with ulceration and induration observed; biopsy confirmed well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma; imaging showed enlarged lymph nodes
Medical_Record.Background: No abnormal blood findings at initial visit; no additional PMH, surgical history, family or social history, medications, allergies, immunizations, or travel history provided

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Tumor with ulceration and induration on right side of tongue, 26 mm diameter
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Hematoxylin–eosin staining: atypical cells in lymph nodes; immunohistochemistry: CD30-positive, PAX5 weakly positive in tumor cells; CT: 24.0 × 19.3 × 14.2-mm contrast-enhanced tongue tumor, hypo-absorption in left level IB and III lymph nodes; MRI: 23.4 × 19.6-mm tongue tumor, DOI 13.9 mm; FDG-PET/CT: SUVmax 14.5 at right lingual border, enlarged lymph nodes with SUVmax 4.10 and 9.00; intraoperative frozen section: metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in left level IB lymph node; postoperative histopathology: one metastatic lymph node at left level IB, three at left level III, no extranodal extension; right cervical lymph node: internal vitreous degeneration, no evidence of squamous cell carcinoma or Hodgkin lymphoma

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Frustrated (Complains about symptoms, challenges the doctor's questions, and sounds irritable.), Speaking Style: Hesitant (Uses fillers like 'um' or 'maybe', pauses often, and avoids direct commitment.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Right nasal obstruction; 1 month duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Mild facial swelling; mild proptosis of right eye; no restriction of eye movements or vision; intraoral obliteration of right buccal sulcus by diffuse bony hard mass; deep mesial class II carious lesion of right maxillary first molar; extrusion of right maxillary first and third molars; grade I painless mobility of right maxillary first and second premolars; missing right mandibular first and third molars with history of extraction after carious exposure 6–8 years ago
Medical_Record.Background: Otherwise healthy; no regional lymphadenopathy; no mention of medications, allergies, family history, social history, immunizations, or travel

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Mild facial swelling; mild proptosis of right eye; intraoral obliteration of right buccal sulcus by bony hard mass; normal oral mucosa; grade I painless mobility of right maxillary first and second premolars; no palpable regional lymph nodes
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Paranasal sinus x-ray: dense sclerotic radiopaque mass obliterating right maxillary sinus with deviated nasal septum; OPG: dense to mixed sclerotic radiopaque mass of right maxillary sinus, widening of periodontal ligament space of right maxillary premolars and molars; CT scan: mixed sclerotic mass involving right maxilla and nasal cavity, involvement of infraorbital floor, nasal cavity, frontal, sphenoidal, and ethmoidal sinuses; Histopathology: sheets of disorganized woven immature bone, round cells with large vesicular nucleus and scanty cytoplasm, focal bizarre multinucleated giant cells, irregular calcified spicules, disorganized immature bone with acid-etched-glass appearance; Chest x-ray: no metastatic lesions

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Forgetful (Mixes up dates, frequently says 'I don't recall', and gives vague details.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Left axillary mass; unknown duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Accidentally found 1.5-cm bulging, red mass in left armpit; no pain; no ulceration; underwent left axillary tumor resection; no recurrence or metastasis during follow-up
Medical_Record.Background: Previously healthy; no other complications; mother with history of breast cancer

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Imaging: No mass in bilateral mammary glands; no enlarged lymph nodes; no organ metastasis. Histology: Adenocarcinoma cells of sweat gland origin coexisting with Paget’s cells. Immunostaining: Strong positive for GCDFP-15, GATA-3, CK, E-cadherin, P120-tcn; partial positive for CK5/6, CK20, P53; negative for ER, PR, P53, Calponin, MelanA, S-100, HMB-45, MUC2. HER2: 2+ by IHC, FISH shows amplification. Ki67: 20% positive. Androgen receptor: 40% positive. Pathology: Small number of atypical cells under mucosa; no axillary lymph node metastasis (0/14).

Diagnosis: Sweat gland carcinoma associated with extramammary Paget’s disease

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Denial (Downplays pain, insists symptoms are minor, and dismisses severity.), Speaking Style: Confused (Misunderstands questions, asks for repetition, and gives unrelated answers.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Incidental liver lesion on MRI; duration 3 years
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Subcapsular cystic liver lesion detected on routine MRI; stable for 2 years; slight increase in size and altered perfusion after 3 years; bile duct dilation; suspicion of malignancy
Medical_Record.Background: Complex renal cysts; arterial hypertension treated with three antihypertensive drugs; steatotic liver; otherwise healthy; no cholestasis; negative serology for echinococci

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: MRI: subcapsular cystic lesion between liver segments V and VIII; CEUS: lesion in liver hilus (1.7 cm) with bile duct dilation; CA 19-9 elevated at 41.3 U/ml; CEA and alpha1-fetoprotein normal; MRCP: intrahepatic lesion (1.7 cm) with bile duct compression; ERCP: slight impression of right hepatic duct, cytology non-diagnostic; LiMAx test: 492 μg/h/kg; Histology: well-/poorly differentiated cholangiocarcinoma (pT2) with two lymph node metastases (pN1)

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Calm (Responds objectively, focuses on facts, and keeps a steady tone.), Speaking Style: Hesitant (Uses fillers like 'um' or 'maybe', pauses often, and avoids direct commitment.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Right ovarian tumor; duration not specified
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Initial right ovarian tumor identified; laparoscopic right salpingo-oophorectomy performed; post-surgical pathology showed Sertoli–Leydig-cell tumor; no virilization or hirsutism; 6 months later, metastatic lesions found in pelvic peritoneum, diaphragm, and trocar site; left ovary solid with suspected tumor spread; multiple recurrences and metastases over several years; persistent disease progression despite multiple surgeries and chemotherapy
Medical_Record.Background: Gravida 2 para 2; unremarkable past medical and surgical history; no relevant family history; no hormonal symptoms; no significant medication or allergy history mentioned

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Histopathology: initial Sertoli–Leydig-cell tumor, later SCT-NOS; immunohistochemistry positive for inhibin A, calretinin, synaptophysin; negative for pan-cytokeratin, CD68, EMA, chromogranin A, ER/AR; Ki-67 up to 15%; normal hormone levels (FSH, LH, prolactin, estradiol, progesterone, testosterone, DHEA-S, cortisol); tumor markers (HE4, β-hCG, AFP) normal; Ca125 elevated to 48.8 kU/L, returned to normal; CT scans: multiple metastatic lesions, disease progression, ascites, hydronephrosis; frozen sections and biopsies confirmed SCT-NOS metastases

Diagnosis: Steroid-cell tumor, not otherwise specified (SCT-NOS) of the ovary with metastases

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Progressive loss of strength; difficulty walking; 5-year duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Onset at age 5; progressive loss of strength; difficulty ambulating due to hypotonia in lower and upper limbs; genu valgus; joint hypermobility; wheelchair dependent by age 10
Medical_Record.Background: No abnormal karyotype; normal muscle enzymes; normal radiologic studies; growth of pubic hair and possible menstrual episode at age 7 with normal LH, FSH, estrogen, and progesterone; pituitary cysts and diffuse hypomyelination on brain MRI; orthopedic surgery for Achilles tendon shortening; curly hair with eyelash involvement; GAN gene mutation c.1456G>A (p.GLU486LYS); died at age 12 due to respiratory complications

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Genu valgus; joint hypermobility; hypotonia in limbs; curly hair; eyelash involvement
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Normal karyotype; normal muscle enzymes; normal radiologic studies; brain MRI: pituitary cysts, diffuse hypomyelination; GAN gene mutation c.1456G>A (p.GLU486LYS); scanning electron microscopy: longitudinal grooves and polygonal hair shape (pili canaliculi)

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Intermittent cough; half-month duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Intermittent cough; chest X-ray shows heart dilation; echocardiography reveals left atrial occupying lesion and large pericardial effusion; pericardiocentesis removes 600 mL bloody effusion; weight loss of 5 kg since onset; pleural effusion detected; thoracocentesis removes 100 mL bloody effusion; episodes of transient hypertension after activity
Medical_Record.Background: No family history of tumors; no environmental exposures; no chemical or radiation exposure; no relevant social history

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Systolic blood pressure 180–200 mmHg after activity; blood pressure normalizes after rest
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Chest X-ray: heart dilation; echocardiography: left atrial lesion (2.8 × 4.5 cm), EF 80%, pericardial effusion; thoracic CT: left atrial lesion (3.44 × 5.54 cm), inhomogeneous enhancement; PET-CT: soft tissue mass (3.5 × 6.5 cm) in left atrium, hypermetabolic brown adipose tissue; pathology: paraganglioma; postoperative catecholamine levels normal

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Sudden right-sided weakness and dysarthria
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Acute onset right-sided weakness; dysarthria; blood pressure 158/94 mm Hg on admission
Medical_Record.Background: History of smoking; chronic nephritis; hypertension; elevated serum creatinine and blood urea; elevated urinary protein; hematuria; renal cyst on ultrasound; no medication or allergy information provided

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Muscle strength grade 3 on admission; improved to grade 5 after treatment; no other physical findings stated
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Brain CT: high-intensity signals at pontine-medullary junction; MRI: acute pontine infarction, two-lumen sign; angiography and MRA: vertebrobasilar dolichoectasia; laboratory: elevated serum creatinine, blood urea, urinary protein, hematuria; renal ultrasound: renal cyst

Diagnosis: Ischemic stroke due to intracranial arterial dolichoectasia and spontaneous basilar artery dissection

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Mild abdominal pain; unknown duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Mild abdominal pain; stable vital signs; good general condition
Medical_Record.Background: History of two previous cesarean sections; history of two previous miscarriages

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Stable vital signs; good general condition
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Ultrasound: empty uterus; gestational sac between uterus and bladder; transvaginal sonography confirmed cesarean scar pregnancy; gestational age 13 weeks (LMP), 12 weeks (CRL); no fetal heart activity; 71×59 mm hematoma around gestational sac; normal full blood count; normal liver and renal function tests; β-hCG 874 IU/mL (day 0), 329 IU/mL (day 7), negative at 8 weeks; mass not visible on ultrasound at 3 months

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Late-onset involuntary movements in tongue and left extremities; 6 months duration after surgery
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Sudden onset visual field disturbance and cognitive dysfunction; diagnosed with Moyamoya disease; developed right homonymous hemianopsia, sensory aphasia, apraxia, agnosia; underwent STA-MCA anastomosis and EDMAPS; uneventful postoperative course; six months after surgery, developed sustained involuntary movements resembling chorea
Medical_Record.Background: No further cerebrovascular events after surgery; treated with clonazepam without improvement; treated with haloperidol with gradual and complete resolution; no recurrence for ten years

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Right homonymous hemianopsia; sensory aphasia; apraxia; agnosia
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Brain MRI: multiple infarctions in bilateral deep frontal lobes, left occipital lobe, right temporoparietal lobes; MRA: severe stenosis in terminal ICAs and posterior cerebral arteries bilaterally; SPECT: reduced cerebral blood flow in bilateral hemispheres; postoperative MRI/MRA: no new abnormalities

Diagnosis: Late-onset chorea after surgical revascularization for pediatric Moyamoya disease

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Incidental high platelet count; recurrent painful erections (stuttering priapism); duration: two to three times per month, lasting 15-60 minutes
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Recurrent painful erections; no trauma; no medication use; no headache, dizziness, tinnitus, chest pain, or bleeding
Medical_Record.Background: Past sleeve gastrectomy (2014) and gastric bypass (2016) for morbid obesity; no family history of hematological or connective tissue diseases; previous normal platelet count until age 50; anemia corrected with iron therapy; ANA and ANCA negative; no urological intervention required

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Platelet count 1189 × 10^3/μL (elevated); hemoglobin 11.2 gm/dL (low); WBC 8.7 × 10^3/μL (normal); iron level 7.00 μmol/L (low); Fe saturation 11% (low); transferrin 2.60 gm/L (normal); ferritin 3.8 mcg/L (low), improved to 529.0 μg/L after therapy; ANA and ANCA negative; BCR/ABL1 t(9;22)(q34;q11.2) negative; JAK2 mutation negative; Type 2 calreticulin mutation positive; bone marrow biopsy: myeloproliferative neoplasm (consistent with ET); peripheral blood smear: increased platelets, some large and few giant forms; chromosomal analysis: normal karyotype (46,XY); US abdomen: normal liver and spleen, no ascites, no organomegaly

Diagnosis: Essential thrombocythemia with type 2 calreticulin mutation

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Abdominal distention; duration not specified
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Abdominal distention; no prior similar symptoms
Medical_Record.Background: History of acute pancreatitis; gravida 2, para 2; no medications; no family history of ovarian or breast cancer

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Serum CA125 1520.5 U/mL (elevated); abdominopelvic MRI: massive ascites, ovarian masses, numerous nodules in abdominal and pelvic cavities; chest CT: left-supraclavicular lymphadenopathy; PET-CT: FDG accumulation in bilateral ovarian masses, left-supraclavicular, peritoneal, para-aortic, intra-pelvic nodules; post-NAC: serum CA125 97.6 U/mL, decreased tumor size, diminished ascites; histology: high-grade nuclear atypia, spread to both ovaries, omentum, uterine serosa, left fallopian tube; immunohistochemistry: absence of p53, overexpression of p16 in cancer cells, overexpression of p53, lack of p16 in adjacent benign epithelium; nuclear expression of γ-H2AX in p53 aberrant lesions; Ki-67 index <5% in benign epithelium, ~15% in tumor cells; TP53 mutation: 1 bp deletion (c.792del1) in exon 8

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Calm (Responds objectively, focuses on facts, and keeps a steady tone.), Speaking Style: Concise (Uses short sentences, answers strictly 'yes' or 'no', and avoids elaboration.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Pre-implantation genetic diagnosis with surrogacy; ongoing reproductive management
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Desire for children while minimizing risk of pregnancy-related complications and transmission of pathogenic COL3A1 variant; history of multiple vascular and connective tissue complications
Medical_Record.Background: Unilateral congenital hip dislocation at birth; left anterior cruciate ligament rupture at age 9; hemorrhagic rupture of liver cyst at age 27; right peroneal arterial aneurysm at age 28; molecularly confirmed vEDS; right coronary artery dissection and right iliac artery dissection at age 29; splenic artery aneurysm rupture during IVF hormonal stimulation at age 32; left-sided deep vein thrombosis post-discharge; liver hematoma; multiple cycles of natural IVF and in vitro maturation; spontaneous dissection of infrarenal aorta with sigmoid volvulus at age 38; successful surrogacy with healthy offspring confirmed negative for familial COL3A1 variant; no reported organ damage or significant bleeds from transvaginal egg retrievals

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Genetic testing confirmed de novo heterozygous pathogenic COL3A1 variant (c.2492G>A, p. Gly831Asp); prenatal and postnatal genetic testing of offspring negative for familial COL3A1 variant

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Right hemiparesis; 1.5-hour duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Acute onset right hemiparesis; no improvement after tPA; developed acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis 6 hours after ITT
Medical_Record.Background: Previously healthy; nonsmoker; no significant past medical history; no drug allergies; negative serologies for ANA, c- and p-ANCA, anti-GBM, IgG ACA, and anti-2GPI antibodies; normal urinalysis

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Body temperature 36.1°C; room air oxygen saturation 95%; cardiac examination shows atrial fibrillation
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: WBC 6.3 × 10^9/L; hematocrit 39%; platelet count 196 × 10^9/L; APTT 35 s; normal PT and INR; NIHSS score 10; initial brain CT excludes bleeding; chest radiography shows bilateral alveolar infiltrates and emphysema; CT pulmonary vasculature shows no emboli; hemoglobin drop from 11.6 to 9.8 g/dL; bronchoscopy reveals diffuse alveolar hemorrhage; control thorax CT after 6 months shows complete resolution

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Optimistic (Focuses on recovery, expresses hope, and uses positive language.), Speaking Style: Verbose (Over-explains, includes irrelevant backstory, and rambles off-topic.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Progressive worsening jerking movement of arms and legs; right torticollis with right shoulder elevation
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Focal segmental myoclonic jerks of arms and trunk; occasional twisting and posturing; dystonic posturing as finger spooning; myoclonus first observed with intentional movement at age four; symptoms worsened over time; frequency increased with anxiety or social situations; no vocal tics; no urge or relief after movements
Medical_Record.Background: Significant acute events of akinesia; past medical history otherwise unremarkable; family history notable for father diagnosed with Tourette’s syndrome during childhood with similar symptoms; no other relevant family history; previously treated with levetiracetam, valproic acid, clonazepam, topiramate, pimozide, risperidone, guanfacine without marked improvement; responsive to carbidopa/levodopa; no reported allergies

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Cranial nerve testing normal; motor and sensory testing normal; dystonic posturing observed; right torticollis with right shoulder elevation
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: EEG: abnormal generalized polyspikes at age seven; 24-hour ambulatory EEG: no epileptiform discharges or asymmetries; brain MRI: no acute intracranial process or cortical abnormalities; Wilson’s disease workup, serum copper, ceruloplasmin, vitamin B-12: within normal limits; whole exome sequencing: SGCE heterozygous pathogenic mutation (c.662+2T>A), FOXRED1 heterozygous pathogenic mutation (c.612_615dup (p.Ala206serfs*15))

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Recurrent urinary tract infections; severe dysuria; bladder pain/discomfort; duration not specified
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: History of hypocontractile bladder after Miles' operation for rectal cancer in 2008; clean intermittent catheterization followed by 7 years of indwelling Foley catheter; recurrent UTIs; severe dysuria; bladder pain/discomfort
Medical_Record.Background: Mild hypertension; taking beta blockers and low-dose aspirin; Miles' operation for rectal cancer in 2008; colostomy present and well functioning; no drug allergies mentioned; no family history mentioned

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Normal systemic parameters; catheter in situ; digital rectal examination impossible due to closed anus; colostomy trophic; abdominal scar smooth and dry; no thoracic or abdominal abnormalities
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Ultrasound: normal upper urinary tract, reduced capacity bladder, 2 cm bladder stone, small volume prostate with calcifications; urine culture positive for Enterobacter cloacae (>106 CFU/mL); serum PSA 1.1 ng/mL; endoscopy: hair nidus in bladder; gross examination: trichobezoar in bladder; histopathology: benign prostatic hyperplasia with chronic inflammation

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Left knee swelling; duration not specified
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Left knee swelling; incidental severe hypocalcemia (2.7 mg/dl); EKG with prolonged QTC (525 ms); no Chvostek or Trousseau's sign; recent denosumab and leuprolide administration; did not take prescribed vitamin D and calcium; recent prednisone course for pseudogout flare
Medical_Record.Background: History of chronic kidney disease, pseudogout, metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (bone, nodes, lung); home medications: acetaminophen, amlodipine, bicalutamide, docusate-senna, lidocaine patches, ondansetron, polyethylene glycol; no vitamin D or calcium supplementation adherence; prior acute kidney injury due to obstructive uropathy; bilateral nephrostomy tubes placed; resumed androgen deprivation therapy; no data on allergies, family, or social history

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Negative for Chvostek and Trousseau's sign
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Calcium 2.7 mg/dl (severe hypocalcemia); EKG: QTC 525 ms; phosphorus 5.5 mg/dl; total vitamin D3 31 IU; iPTH 93; magnesium 1.1 mg/dl; creatinine worsened to 7.5 mg/dl; severe metabolic acidosis; hyponatremia; Clostridium difficile colitis; PSA 1472; BUN 131 mg/dl; CT: bilateral hydronephrosis, 6.3 cm pelvic mass, 3.8 cm left ureteropelvic junction mass, extensive lymphadenopathy, metastatic lytic skeletal lesions

Diagnosis: Severe hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia induced by denosumab in advanced chronic kidney disease

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Calm (Responds objectively, focuses on facts, and keeps a steady tone.), Speaking Style: Concise (Uses short sentences, answers strictly 'yes' or 'no', and avoids elaboration.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Right breast mass; 2-month duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Progressive right breast mass; diagnosed as invasive ductal breast cancer; refractory to chemotherapy; tumor increased in size; developed dyspnea; multiple lung metastases; cancerous lymphangiopathy; recurrence 9 months after surgery
Medical_Record.Background: Asthma; schizophrenia; mother died of endometrial cancer at 57; no other family history of cancers; germline PTEN gene alteration; no medication or allergy information

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Core-needle biopsy: invasive ductal carcinoma, ER/PR/HER2 negative, Ki-67 >90%, histological grade 3; mammography: indistinct high-density mass; ultrasonography: irregular low echoic mass 39×20×18 mm; PET-CT: abnormal uptake in right breast, axillary lymph node, left cerebellar hemisphere; brain MRI: hyperintense bands, tiger-stripe appearance, diagnosed as Lhermitte-Duclos disease; genetic testing: PTEN gene c.823_840del.18 at exon 8; postoperative pathology: invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 3, pT3 (51 mm) N3a (10/29) M0 stage IIIC; pleural effusion; lung metastases

Diagnosis: Triple-negative breast cancer with Cowden syndrome

Medical_Record.Background: History of atrial fibrillation; on warfarin and digoxin; no other past medical history, surgical history, family or social history, allergies, or immunization status mentioned

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Glasgow coma scale 13; dysarthria; bilateral lower limbs pitting edema to knee; blood pressure 130/70 mmHg; heart rate 90 bpm (atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular response); respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute; oxygen saturation 96% (nasal oxygen cannula 2 L/min); not cooperative for conscious prone positioning
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: MRI: bilateral acute midbrain and thalamic infarction; Blood tests: INR 1.03, ferritin 1200 ng/mL, troponin 10 ng/L, D-dimer 2.3 mg/mL, CRP 161 mg/L, normal kidney and liver function; Transthoracic echocardiogram: LVEF 60%, moderate mitral and tricuspid regurgitation, dilated right atrium and right ventricle, pulmonary hypertension, RVSP 64 mmHg; Chest CT: bilateral ground-glass appearance, sub-pleural consolidation right lung; ABG: P/F 280, later 180; CVP 15-18 mmHg; UOP 0.5 mL/kg/hour; TTE: dilated pulmonary arteries, right atrium, right ventricle, mild RV free wall hypokinesia, no visible thrombi in main pulmonary artery, dilated IVC with collapse <50%, normal LV; CT pulmonary angiography: right middle lobar segmental branch occlusion (thrombosis); high fibrinogen degradation products (280 mg/mL); lactic metabolic acidosis

Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Recurrent fever and loose stools; duration more than 3 months; aggravation for 3 days
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Fever and loose stools began 3 months ago; initially diagnosed as acute gastroenteritis; symptoms persisted and worsened; stools yellow, watery, no blood; multiple hospital visits; no improvement
Medical_Record.Background: No remarkable history of past illness

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Pale mucosa; upper abdominal tenderness
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: WBC 9.9 × 10^9/L; neutrophil ratio 75.7%; hemoglobin 87 g/L; C-reactive protein 106 mg/L; procalcitonin 3.92 ng/mL; calprotectin and ANCA IgG positive; negative autoantibody, immunization, blood culture, stool culture, Widal reaction, CMV DNA, and IBD-associated antibodies; B-ultrasound: multiple cervical and mesenteric lymph nodes; colonoscopy: multiple colonic ulcers; colonoscopic biopsy: chronic mucosal inflammation, interstitial lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophil and neutrophil infiltration; immunohistochemistry: chronic inflammation of sigmoid mucosa, T lymphocyte hyperplasia; PET-CT: increased 18F-FDG metabolism in colon and rectum, slight thickening of colon wall, multiple low-metabolized mesenteric lymph nodes; high fever up to 40.3°C; WBC 17.5 × 10^9/L; neutrophil ratio 91.8%; enteroscopy: hyperemia and edema of sigmoid colon mucosa, multiple longitudinal ulcers, proliferative changes; bone marrow aspiration: 3.5% lymphocytes, mainly mature; bone marrow immunohistochemistry: CD3, CD2, CD5, CD20, CD79α, myeloperoxidase, CD61, CD34 positive; TdT negative; blood tumor immunotyping: increased granulocytes, abnormal differentiation; Ig gene rearrangement: no monoclonal rearrangement; pathology: focal heterotypic lymphocyte infiltration, abnormal immune phenotype; CD3, EBER, TIA positive; CD20, CD5, CD4, CD8 negative; CD56 suspected positive; Ki-67 approximately 40%

Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Recurrent crusted macule with small erosions on upper lip; flares lasting weeks then healing; no improvement with over-the-counter cold sore medication; no pain, tingling, or burning; lesion visually unchanged over time; no response to oral valacyclovir
Medical_Record.Background: No significant past medical history; no history of cold sores; medication: oral valacyclovir; no information on surgical history, family history, social history, allergies, immunizations, or travel

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: 7-mm erythematous crusted papule with slightly pearly rolled borders on upper lip
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Tzanck smear: multinucleated giant cells; tangential biopsy: basal cell carcinoma; Mohs stage I: multinucleated giant cells adjacent to residual basal cell carcinoma

Diagnosis: Basal cell carcinoma of the upper lip

Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: 2 cm lesion detected; biopsy revealed neuroendocrine neoplasm (G1)
Medical_Record.Background: History of left upper lobectomy for lung cancer (pT2aN0M0, stage IB) 1 year ago; adjuvant chemotherapy with tegafur-uracil for 8 months

Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Endoscopic ultrasonography: 14 mm submucosal lesion; CT and duodenography: 18-mm tumor in descending duodenum; Intraoperative endoscopy: tumor protruding from duodenum; Pathology: duodenal neuroendocrine neoplasm, G1

Medical_Record.Personality: Emotion: Skeptical (Doubts the diagnosis, questions the doctor's logic, and asks for proof.), Speaking Style: Verbose (Over-explains, includes irrelevant backstory, and rambles off-topic.)
Medical_Record.Chief_Complaint: Dysphagia; 2-month duration
Medical_Record.History_of_Present_Illness: Progressive dysphagia; only able to consume fluids; weight loss of 8 kg (9% of initial body weight) over 2 months; further weight loss of 25 kg (36% of initial body weight) over next 4 months; total weight at referral 83 kg, later 58 kg
Medical_Record.Background: Diabetes mellitus type II; hypertension; history of benign colon polyps (three polypectomies); 50-year tobacco use (10 cigarettes daily); no alcohol overconsumption; no HIV, herpes, or HPV infection; hospitalized at Department of Infectious Diseases during workup

Clinical_Findings.Physical_Examination: Unremarkable initial examination
Clinical_Findings.Investigations: Initial blood tests unremarkable; primary endoscopy: white plaques from 30 to 40 cm from incisors, mucosa protruding and covering almost 2/3 of lumen; initial biopsies: severe acute inflammation with reactive changes, no dysplasia or malignancy; CT: thickened wall in distal esophagus; repeat gastroscopy: ulceration and protruding process; biopsy: squamous cell papilloma; PET-CT: no explanation for symptoms; high-resolution impedance manometry: achalasia ruled out; final pathology: low-grade verrucous squamous cell carcinoma, no lymph node or organ dissemination

Diagnosis: Verrucous squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus
